23.words: After the 737 Max crash in Indonesia, the FAA learned it was possible some systems in the Boeing 737 Max could fail. Later, when explaining their decision not to ground the plane, they said the chance was as close to zero as their calculations allowed considering the number of planes in the air. That choice prompted a congressional investigation in 2018 and ultimately led to changes in how the FAA certifies planes back in 2024. After the Alaska Airlines incident, the FAA immediately grounded other similar 737 Max planes for inspection.

68.words: Since I mentioned earlier about how I travel in planes a lot, they're always playing those safety videos at the beginning and I don't watch them anymore. I just ignore them. And if the person is doing a live demonstration, I will do anything to not look at them, even if it means I have to actively turn my head, I don't want to hear it. And so, sometimes when I'm actively turning my head away from them, someone I'm sitting with will be like, "Don't you want to pay attention?" And then I'm like, "Oh, if the plan goes down, is there anything I can do about it? No." So I feel like I've gotten desensitized to it. And this kind of ties into, I feel like I've talked about this a lot with people lately, but Gen Z humor and it just being really morbid and not caring about anything. 73.words: As a layover. I went to Atlanta for a layover. The flight in was delayed a lot because they were having tech issues with getting a flight attendant on. And when we actually got to Atlanta, it was very clear that there were a lot of people who had not gotten out and weren't able to. Every rental car in a 40-mile radius was completely and utterly sold out. You couldn't get a train ticket out. Delta couldn't pay back everybody at once because it was just such an insane volume. The helplines to get to the help desk wrapped through the hallways. I have photos and videos of it. It is one of the most incredible just volumes of people I've ever seen in one place. And the energy in the room, everyone's anxious, babies are crying, people have been there. We were in line for something. And I remember this woman comes up to me and she's crying and she's like, "Hey, I'm so sorry to ask you this, but can you please save a place for us in this line? I've been here for three days, I can't get out. I have three little kids and I don't know what to do." And just seeing how something so simple as Windows going down could so significantly impact thousands of people in such a profound way. And honestly, I kind of feel a little bit guilty every time I do talk about it because I was lucky I got out that same day. I was at the airport for what? 12 hours, which I was one of the luckiest people I talked to. There was a woman who said that she'd been awake for 30 hours straight. People sleeping all over the airport floor. And it was, I don't want to sound like I'm a jerk when I complain about it, but yeah, it was something else. And it really shows you how dependent we are as a culture on travel like this running smoothly.
